channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Suicide Attacks and Bombings Leave More Than 30 Dead in Iraq
item.description: One of the attacks killed the police chief of Anbar Province, dealing a blow to the efforts of Iraq’s security forces to wrest control of the area from militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Obama’s Top Military Adviser Warns of Possible ISIS Attacks in Baghdad
item.description: Islamic State fighters are blending in with disenfranchised Sunni populations in some Iraqi cities near the capital, Gen. Martin E. Dempsey said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How to Quarantine Against Ebola
item.description: Create a rapid blood-testing system for travelers from affected regions.
item.dc:creator: By SIDDHARTHA MUKHERJEE

item.title: International Education: Japan's Divided Education Strategy
item.description: The government wants to rewrite textbooks to make wartime history more “patriotic.” But at the same time, it wants to project an open, international image.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FITZPATRICK
item.media:description: Japan’s conservatives returned to power last year with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at their head.

item.title: International Education: Online Magazine Brings New Life to Arab Studies
item.description: Jadaliyya, a publication run mostly by dedicated volunteers, allows for a broad range of opinions on the Middle East.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By URSULA LINDSEY | THE CHRONICLE OF HIGHER EDUCATION
item.media:description: Last month, Jadaliyya ran an interview with Maryam al-Khawaja, a Bahraini activist who had been arrested.

item.title: International Education: Turkish Reforms Entangle Education
item.description: Secularism in schools has been undergoing a transformation that signals a reticence on the part of the government to separate religion from politics.
item.dc:creator: By AYSEGUL SERT

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: A Cure for Hyper-Parenting
item.description: I used to think that only Americans and Brits did helicopter parenting. In fact, it's now a global trend.
item.dc:creator: By PAMELA DRUCKERMAN

item.title: 300,000 Evacuated as Strong Cyclone Hits Eastern India
item.description: One of the regions worst affected by the storm was the coast of Andhra Pradesh, where at least two people were killed.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR and SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:description: Heavy rain and wind from Cyclone Hudhud battered the eastern coast of India on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Pledges $212 Million in New Aid for Gaza
item.description: The money will be used to buy food and medicine, Secretary of State John Kerry said, and to repair infrastructure damaged in the latest conflict between Hamas and Israel.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: The ruins of a neighborhood in Gaza, which was battered during the recent 50-day war between the militant group Hamas and Israel.

item.title: Hong Kong Protesters Appeal to Xi Jinping in Open Letter
item.description: A request by students for the reversal of an election decision has been rejected by the city’s leader, Leung Chun-ying, who has called their movement “out of control.”
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Counterdemonstrators attended a rally against pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong’s Mongkok shopping district on Sunday.

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: In Travel Out of Liberia, Nothing Is Simply Routine
item.description: A reporter takes the same route from Liberia to the United States as Thomas Eric Duncan, the man who, after traveling on to Dallas, fell to the disease.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Amid Ebola Crisis, Liberian Army Sees Its Chance at Rebranding
item.description: The Liberian Army, working alongside American troops, has become a linchpin in the fight against the Ebola virus. But it faces a wary public.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: A Liberian soldier and a United States Marine took cover as a V-22 Osprey buzzed overhead in Tubmanburg, north of Monrovia.

item.title: Aviation Giant Is Nearly Grounded in Ukraine
item.description: The sprawling campus where the Antonov company once designed and built prototypes of the world’s largest transport aircraft — flying whales whose very bulk symbolized Soviet might — lacks buzz these days.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Antonov-225 Mriya on an airfield in Gostomel, near Kiev.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Pink Diamond Auction in Hong Kong Sets World Record
item.description: A fancy pink diamond auctioned in Hong Kong this week set a world record, according to Sotheby’s, and some jade jewelry that once belonged to Wan Rong, the last empress of China, was sold, too.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW and JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: More than 200 people attended the bidding at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center in Wan Chai. The final purchase was made over the phone by a buyer Sotheby's described only as an "Asian private collector."

item.title: Investigation Into Missing Iraqi Cash Ended in Lebanon Bunker
item.description: Between $1.2 billion and $1.6 billion in Iraqi funds were stolen after the American invasion and moved to rural Lebanon, a former United States investigator said for the first time, but the trail ended there.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES RISEN
item.media:credit: Christoph Bangert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stuart W. Bowen Jr., left, a special inspector general who examined corruption and waste in Iraq.

item.title: China Detains Scholar and Rights Activist
item.description: Guo Yushan is the latest of dozens of people rounded up in China against a backdrop of pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Some Remains in Mexico Are Not of Missing Students
item.description: The governor of Guerrero said that some of the 28 burned bodies found last week could not be identified as any of the 43 college students who had disappeared after clashing with the police.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Four Bombings Kill Over 50 People Around Baghdad
item.description: No one claimed responsibility, but Sunni insurgents, including members of the Islamic State, frequently attack majority-Shiite neighborhoods like those hit.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Iran’s Jailing of Activist Offers Hint of Liberty Under Rouhani
item.description: The detention without charge of a 25-year-old Iranian-British national who fought for women’s rights has shown, many say, the limits of personal expression in Iran.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A protester held aloft an image of Ghoncheh Ghavami, 25, a detainee in Iran, as President Hassan Rouhani, left, spoke with Fareed Zakaria, a journalist, at a New York think tank last month.

item.title: Dam Rising in Ethiopia Stirs Hope and Tension
item.description: Ethiopia is a poor country, but officials say the Renaissance Dam, one of Africa’s most ambitious infrastructure projects, will be paid for without foreign assistance.
item.dc:creator: By JACEY FORTIN
item.media:credit: Jacey Fortin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main component of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam, along the Blue Nile, is 32 percent complete.

item.title: Leader Taps Into Chinese Classics in Seeking to Cement Power
item.description: Far more than his predecessors, China’s president has reached back into a rich trove of ancient statecraft for vindication and guidance.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: China watchers have focused on whether President Xi Jinping has the traits of a new Mao, the ruthless revolutionary, or a new Deng Xiaoping, the economic reformer.

item.title: Tracking India’s Bureaucrats Becomes a Digital Dashboard Venture
item.description: A new surveillance system requires government officials to register their presence at the entrance to their offices using a biometric scan of a fingerprint or iris.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India on Oct. 9. He has made it clear he plans to keep government officials on task.

item.title: North Korea Warns South Over Leaflets
item.description: After South Korean activists sent anti-Pyongyang leaflets across the border and troops from both sides exchanged fire, the state news agency said talks with Seoul could be canceled.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Boko Haram Hostages Freed in North, Cameroon Says
item.description: Twenty-seven hostages presumed to have been kidnapped in May and July by the Nigerian group Boko Haram “are safe and sound,” according to a statement from the president’s office.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Hundreds Attend Duvalier's Funeral in Haiti
item.description: The former dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, known as “Baby Doc,” was buried on Saturday, as many Haitians displayed lingering respect for a man who was widely reviled.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A man shouted his support for Jean-Claude Duvalier, the Haitian dictator known as Baby Doc, after his funeral in Port-au-Prince on Saturday. Mr. Duvalier died last Saturday at age 63.
